Award.AwardTitle: SG: A Rapid and Systematic Search for a Mechanism of Self-Incompatibility in Flowering Plants
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will create a database of the molecular basis of self-incompatibility systems in flowering plants. Genetic mechanisms that prevent self-fertilization are common in flowering plants. The distribution, causes, and consequences of these systems remain deeply controversial and are poorly known. A single genetic mechanism is likely ancestral to the group of flowering plants that makes up the majority of species, and that mechanism appears to strongly affect the origin and persistence of species. Although the molecular details are partly known, the current understanding is limited by the availability of data. This project aims to systematically unify diverse sources of data, as well as expand the understanding of history, molecular causes, and consequences of self-incompatibility systems. The resulting database will be of considerable use to a variety of fields from plant breeding, horticulture and restoration ecology to basic plant molecular biology.

This project will: (1) collect the scattered data on the distribution of self-incompatibility across core eudicots and publish it as an important shared community resource for biologists and laypersons, and (2) sequence reproductive tissue transcriptomes (mRNA) and characterize the expression of candidate genes involved in a particular kind of (RNase-based) self-incompatibility. Together, this will allow examination of the weight of evidence supporting the extent of shared ancestry of these widespread genetic mechanisms, which prevent self-fertilization and profoundly affect the fate of flowering plant species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We accomplished each of the major aims, which proposed at the project onset to: (1) systematically collect data on the distribution of self-incompatibility (SI), and publish it as an important shared community resource for biologists and laypersons (Kattge et al. 2019), (2) sequence the sexual tissue transcriptomes (RNA-seq) and characterize the expression of candidate genes involved in RNase-based self-incompatibility (RSI; Ramanauskas and Igic 2017, 2021, & in prep.), as well as (3) examine the weight of evidence supporting the extent of shared ancestry of these widespread genetic mechanisms, which prevent self-fertilization and profoundly affect the evolutionary fate of flowering plants (Ramanauskas and Igic 2017, 2021, & in prep.).


The most exciting and novel outcome of this work concerns the discovery of S-RNase based self-incompatibility in a four new plant families, including Cactaceae and Primulaceae (Ramanauskas and Igic 2021, in prep.). These findings provide great weight of evidence that RSI was present in the common ancestor of the majority of flowering plants. The discovery enables immediate and highly practical applications. Specifically, hundreds of species of cacti, especially some of the most stately and charismatic species, are 'listed' (designated by IUCN as rare, threatened, and endangered). Now that the molecular basis of SI is understood, both wild and 'captive' plant populations can be assessed for diversity of alleles that govern this phenomenon (SI). Such assessment helps preserve maximally diverse germplasm, which in turn helps preservation of less extinction-prone plant populations.


In the course of the project, Ramanauskas (graduate student) and P.I. Igic traveled widely to collect flowering plants from natural populations, as well as conservatory and glasshouse holdings of institutions such as the UCLA and Huntington Botanical Gardens, which were indispensable for their ability to provide us with accessioned (documented) species that rarely flower or are threatened/difficult to collect in the wild. 


One major side product concerns the development of a pipeline for analysis of RNA sequecing data (named 'kakapo', Ramanauskas and Igic, in prep). It will enable other groups to analyze similar data from a variety fo systems. We recently additionally employed it to initiate an international collaboration involving researchers from Seville (Spain) and Santa Clara (USA), published in S?nchez-Cabrera et al. (2021). The award enabled K. Ramanauskas to obtain a range of critical skills at the onset of a career as a professional scientist.
